Original_notes: (+) ?; Pre-European population difficult to estimate and archaeology insufficient. 500 is possible; [- according to Barbara’s source, 303]
[why not +? Barbara also gives -]; large 50’×50’ wooden houses in which ceremonies were held for sizable gatherings of several hundred people
and inside house posts and [unreadable] beams
again the houses were very large and substantive, though of wood
clover [?]; over fishing grounds, berry-picking, mountain goat hunting sites – not “improved”
but temporary i.e. before and after potlatching
economic [underlined] - > potlatch which economic in peculiar sense
in pre-contact times: cedar bark and fur wampums and canoes; [Barbara -]
(The “coppers” are not coined money but have to be taken into consideration)
borderline. The Nootka route took more than a day often
(-); seals, salmon etc. to numaym chief; [Barbara -]
frequent placing of luxury goods in coffins – once burial
(commendation by chiefs, recounting of enemies killed)
supernatural power so attained; right to perform certain ceremonials so attained
? meaning here. Certain supernatural beings having to do with war also had to do with ceremonialism[?]
why omit animals – e.g. crows – how they behave and can foretells war etc.
The sun is a supernatural being, if not a god and not worshiped; [Barbara +, 277]
supernatural beings are represented in carvings – house and other poles
shamans have different specialties, e.g. curing, sorcery, etc.
what to do with Kwakiutl ceremonialists, e.g. Cannibal Dancers?
seclusion in woods for learning ceremonial procedures
fine painters and sculptrors, if not full-time ones
great special war canoes, if not “navy”
why [excluding measurements with parts of the body]?
